_exec_summary.SummaryText:
45th Space Wing hazardous Materials Response Plan;
Cape Canaveral Emergency Management Plan (CCEMP) 


Lockheed Martin Astronautics (LMA) is the prime contractor for the Process 3 operation at CCAFS.  Under LMA's contract with the Air Force, LMA's contractural requirements are that LMA follow the directives in the 32-1 45th Space Wing Disaster Preparednes Operations Plan.  Therefore, there is one consolodated emergency response plan to be implemented by LMA in the event of an emergency.

Facility identification and regulated substances covered processes

CCAFS is located near the city of Cape Canaveral, Florida in Brevard County.  Hydrazine and 1,1-Dimethythydrazide (within a mixture called Aerozine-50) are stored at CCAFS in Complex 40.  Hydrazine and 1,1-Dimethythydrazide are stored above the threshhold limit of 10,000 lbs (89,250 and 85,750 lbs, respectively).  CCAFS stores hydrogen above the threshold limit also; however, it is exempt from the RMP requirements of such due to the Fuels Relief Act.

Prevention Program

The Process 3 at CCAFS, a mixture of hydrazine and 1,1-dimethythyrazide is mandated by federal regulations to have a prevention program.  The Process 3 prevention program includes a Process Hazardous Analysis (PHA), training, maintenance, management of change, a pre-start review, compliance audits, incident investigations, employee participation, hot work permits, and contractor safety procedures.  There numerous regulatory mandates pertaining to the Prevention Program that must be adhered to in order for the RMP to be adequately up-to-date and compliant with 40 CFR 68 regulatory requirements.  The following are regulatory requirements of the Prevention Program Program that CCAFS personnel review before each launch:

Major Hazards Identified
Process Controls in Use
Mitigation Systems in Use
Monitoring/Detection Systems in Use
Review of Operating Procedures
Continuous Training
Proper Maintenance
Management of Change
Pre-Startup Review

Additionally,

Compliance Audits and Process Hazardous Analysis are performed on a regular basis.

Planned Updates

The Titan launches will occur into 2005.  Updates on all RMP requirements will be performed before each launch.

Five-year accident history

There has been no reportable accident within the last five years of this update.

CCAFS coordinates emergency response activities as the situation dictates with the Office of Emergency Management (the local LEPC), and the local port and county authorities as required by 40 CFR 68.12 (b)(3)).

CCAFS also notifies certain local, state, and federal emergency planning and response agencies depending upon whether there is a reportable spill.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

CCAFS is now and has always been cognizant of the importance of safety and emergency preparedness.  Therefore, an ongoing and continuous effort to minimize exposure risks to CCAFS and the surrounding population is incorporated into the daily activities at CCAFS.  CCAFS provides ongoing inspections and documented compliance with applicable regulatory requirements.  CCAFS has no new safety improvements planned at this time.
